p: Quercetin has been confirmed to be a long-acting anti-inflammatory substance in flavonoids [ 64, 65]. Both in animal and in human models, quercetin can show significant anti-inflammatory potential in different cell types [ 66, 67]. The plant extract of quercetin is used as the main component of many potential antiallergic drugs. Compared with Cromolin (the antiallergic drug disodium cromoglycate), its ability to inhibit IL-8 is stronger and can inhibit IL-6 and increase cytosolic calcium levels [ 68]. Its anti-inflammatory and antiallergic properties have been validated in the treatment of respiratory and food allergies [ 69, 70]. In addition to a wide range of biochemical and pharmacological activities, quercetin has been repeatedly shown to exert anti-inflammatory effects on endothelial and monocyte/macrophage systems in vitro [ 71, 72].
